articles.title: The EU has so far allocated the Czech Republic 75 percent of the subsidies earmarked for the period 2021 to 2027
articles.summary: Of the total amount of 512.4 billion crowns, 384 billion crowns was allocated to specific projects, but only 172 billion crowns has so far actually been paid out to the Czech Republic. Requests for 131 billion crowns have been sent to the European Commission for payment.
articles.content:
Of the total amount of 512.4 billion crowns, 384 billion crowns was allocated to specific projects, but only 172 billion crowns has so far actually been paid out to the Czech Republic. Requests for 131 billion crowns have been sent to the European Commission for payment.

Prague – The European Union has so far allocated the Czech Republic 75 percent of the subsidies earmarked for the period 2021 to 2027. Of the total amount of 512.4 billion crowns, 384 billion crowns were designated for specific projects, but only 172 billion crowns have actually been paid out to the Czech Republic so far. Requests for 131 billion crowns have been sent to the European Commission for reimbursement. The Ministry of Regional Development (MMR) announced this in a press release published on its website.

According to the ministry, it has managed to meet the spending limit set by the so-called n+3 rule, which determines the deadline for using the allocated funds. The rule defines that the support earmarked for projects for a given year must be used no later than in the following three calendar years. Given that the limit has been met, the MMR therefore believes there is no risk that the Czech Republic will have to return any money to the European Union budget.

“We are successfully providing money for regional development for the implementation of projects across the Czech Republic. The figures show that the system works. We are meeting the European spending limits without reservation, so we are not returning any funds to Brussels,” said Minister for Regional Development Zuzana Mrázová (ANO).

European funds have supported, for example, the Salvage project at the Masaryk Memorial Cancer Institute in Brno, which, with the help of new technologies and approaches, focuses on improving the prevention of cancer diseases. A total of 488 million crowns from EU funds was earmarked for linking research with clinical practice. The municipalities of Rapotín, Petrov nad Desnou and Vikýřovice in the Šumperk region then used European money, in cooperation with the Morava River Basin Authority, to build flood control measures on the Desná River. The EU contributed 322 million crowns to the creation of an oxbow lake, pools and floodplain parks.

From a report on the risks and measures in the implementation of EU funds, which the MMR published last spring, it emerged that the Czech Republic must speed up the drawing of European subsidies from some operational programmes in 2025. Otherwise, there was a risk that it would not use the allocated money in time and would lose part of it. The risk mainly concerned the Just Transition operational programme, which serves to improve conditions in regions that were or are largely dependent on coal mining. In the event of insufficiently fast drawing from this programme, the Czech Republic could potentially lose between one and four billion crowns. (16 January)

articles.personality_title: Czech Republic successfully uses 75% of EU subsidies for regional projects
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The European Union (EU) has set aside money to support projects in member countries between 2021 and 2027. These funds help improve health care, protect the environment, and support local communities.

**What happened** – So far, the Czech Republic has been allocated 75 percent of its EU subsidy budget, which is about 384 billion Czech crowns out of a total 512.4 billion crowns. Of this, 172 billion crowns have already been paid out to the country, and requests for another 131 billion crowns are being processed by the European Commission. The Czech Ministry of Regional Development said the country is meeting EU rules on how quickly the money must be spent.

**Impact** – This progress means the Czech Republic is successfully using EU money to fund important projects. For example, funds helped the Masaryk Memorial Cancer Institute in Brno improve cancer prevention with new technology. Other money was used to build flood control systems along the Desná River, protecting local towns from flooding. Because the country meets spending deadlines, it avoids losing any funds back to the EU. This careful management shows the Czech Republic is making good use of the support to improve health and safety.

**What's next step** – The government needs to continue speeding up spending, especially on programs like the Just Transition project, which helps areas affected by coal mining. If the country does not use the funds fast enough, it risks losing some money. Officials are watching this closely to make sure all the subsidies are fully used before the deadlines.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The Czech Republic is effectively using most of its EU subsidies to support health, safety, and regional development projects while meeting spending rules to keep the funding.
articles.personality_title_fr: La République tchèque utilise avec succès 75 % des subventions de l’UE pour des projets régionaux
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L’Union européenne (UE) a réservé des fonds pour soutenir des projets dans les pays membres entre 2021 et 2027. Ces fonds aident à améliorer les soins de santé, protéger l’environnement et soutenir les communautés locales.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Jusqu’à présent, la République tchèque a reçu 75 % de son budget de subventions de l’UE, soit environ 384 milliards de couronnes tchèques sur un total de 512,4 milliards. Sur ce montant, 172 milliards ont déjà été versés au pays, et des demandes pour 131 milliards supplémentaires sont en cours d’examen par la Commission européenne. Le ministère tchèque du Développement régional a déclaré que le pays respecte les règles de l’UE sur la rapidité avec laquelle l’argent doit être dépensé.

**Impact** – Cette avancée signifie que la République tchèque utilise avec succès l’argent de l’UE pour financer des projets importants. Par exemple, des fonds ont aidé l’Institut du cancer Masaryk à Brno à améliorer la prévention du cancer grâce à de nouvelles technologies. D’autres fonds ont servi à construire des systèmes de contrôle des inondations sur la rivière Desná, protégeant les villes locales. Comme le pays respecte les délais de dépense, il évite de perdre des fonds au profit de l’UE. Cette bonne gestion montre que la République tchèque utilise bien ce soutien pour améliorer la santé et la sécurité.

**Prochaine étape** – Le gouvernement doit continuer à accélérer les dépenses, surtout pour des programmes comme la Transition juste, qui aide les régions touchées par l’exploitation du charbon. Si le pays ne dépense pas les fonds assez vite, il risque de perdre une partie de l’argent. Les responsables surveillent cela pour s’assurer que toutes les subventions soient utilisées avant les délais.

**Phrase clé** – La République tchèque utilise efficacement la majorité de ses subventions européennes pour soutenir des projets de santé, de sécurité et de développement régional tout en respectant les règles de dépense pour conserver les fonds.
articles.personality_title_es: República Checa utiliza con éxito el 75 % de las subvenciones de la UE para proyectos regionales
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La Unión Europea (UE) ha reservado dinero para apoyar proyectos en países miembros entre 2021 y 2027. Estos fondos ayudan a mejorar la atención médica, proteger el medio ambiente y apoyar a las comunidades locales.

**Qué pasó** – Hasta ahora, la República Checa ha recibido el 75 % de su presupuesto de subvenciones de la UE, que equivale a unos 384 mil millones de coronas checas de un total de 512,4 mil millones. De esta cantidad, ya se han pagado 172 mil millones, y se están procesando solicitudes por otros 131 mil millones ante la Comisión Europea. El Ministerio de Desarrollo Regional de la República Checa dijo que el país cumple con las reglas de la UE sobre la rapidez con que se debe gastar el dinero.

**Impacto** – Este avance significa que la República Checa está usando con éxito el dinero de la UE para financiar proyectos importantes. Por ejemplo, los fondos ayudaron al Instituto de Cáncer Masaryk en Brno a mejorar la prevención del cáncer con nuevas tecnologías. Otro dinero se usó para construir sistemas de control de inundaciones en el río Desná, protegiendo a pueblos locales. Como el país cumple con los plazos de gasto, evita perder fondos que tendrían que devolver a la UE. Esta buena gestión muestra que la República Checa aprovecha bien el apoyo para mejorar la salud y la seguridad.

**Próximo paso** – El gobierno debe seguir acelerando el gasto, especialmente en programas como el de Transición Justa, que ayuda a las regiones afectadas por la minería del carbón. Si el país no usa los fondos lo suficientemente rápido, corre el riesgo de perder parte del dinero. Los funcionarios están atentos para asegurarse de que todas las subvenciones se usen antes de los plazos.

**Frase clave** – La República Checa está utilizando eficazmente la mayoría de sus subvenciones de la UE para apoyar proyectos de salud, seguridad y desarrollo regional, cumpliendo las reglas de gasto para conservar los fondos.
